title: Introduction to PRECISION.seq.augmented package
text: PRECISION.seq.augmented package provides comprehensive framework clustering analysis sequencing data two-stage pipeline: Data Harmonization: first crucial step involves harmonizing sequencing data ensure consistency compatibility across different samples. package, 9 different data harmonization methods, including: Trimmed mean M-values (TMM) Total count harmonization (TC) Upper quantile harmonization (UQ) Median harmonization (med) Quantile harmonization (QU) DESeq harmonization (DESeq) PossionSeq harmonization (PossionSeq) Quantile normalization (QN) Surrogate Variable Analysis (SVA) RUV normalization (RUVg, RUVr, RUVs) ComBat-Seq harmonization (ComBat-Seq) Clustering Analysis: Following data harmonization, one can perform clustering analysis using following clustering methods: K-means clustering (kmeans) Hierarchical clustering (hc) Self-organizing map (SOM) Gaussian mixture model (MNM) PAM clustering (pam.eucledian, pam.pearson, pam.spearman)

title: Introduction to PRECISION.seq.augmented package
text: ’s basic example perform clustering analysis:
code: # Step 0: Prepare the 'precision' object example_cluster <- create.precision.cluster(data = data.test, label = data.group)  # Step 1: Harmonize via all the methods example_cluster <- harmon.all(example_cluster)  # Step 2: Clustering via all the methods example_cluster <- cluster.all(example_cluster)  # Step 4: Measure the consistency between the clustering labels and the true labels cluster <- c("kmeans", "hc", "som", "mnm", "pam.euclidean", "pam.pearson", "pam.spearman") harmon <- c("Raw", "TC", "UQ", "med", "TMM", "DESeq", "PoissonSeq", "QN", "RUVg", "RUVs", "RUVr") ari_indexes <- data.frame(matrix(nrow = length(cluster), ncol = length(harmon))) true_label <- as.factor(c(rep("MXF", 27), rep("PMFH", 27))) for (i in seq_along(cluster)) {   for (j in seq_along(harmon)) {     eval(parse(text = paste0("est_cluster <-", "example_cluster@cluster.result", "$", cluster[i], "$", harmon[j])))     ari_indexes[i, j] <- mclust::adjustedRandIndex(true_label, est_cluster)   } } rownames(ari_indexes) <- cluster colnames(ari_indexes) <- harmon

code: @Manual{,   title = {PRECISION.seq.augmented: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data},   author = {Jian Zou and Ying Xiang and Yilin Wu and Yannick Düren},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://omics-data-harmonization-ebp.github.io/PRECISION.seq.augmented/}, }

what: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: PRECISION.seq.augmented R package offers comprehensive framework evaluating depth normalization methods microRNA sequencing data analysis. allows investigating normalization performance clustering classification contexts provides researchers tools assess different normalization approaches affect analytical outcomes. Using AI-augmented miRNA-seq data derived paired benchmark test datasets, package enables systematic comparison across controlled conditions varying biological signal strengths technical artifact magnitudes. PRECISION.seq.augmented implements multiple normalization techniques, clustering approaches, classification algorithms, allowing researchers identify optimal strategies specific analytical needs reproduce findings publications. package represents essential resource researchers seeking maximize reliability reproducibility insights derived miRNA sequencing data.

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: can install released version PRECISION.seq.augmented directly GitHub using devtools: R package PoissonSeq PoissonSeq normalization removed CRAN, can install archived version GitHub: successful installation, ensure dependencies properly installed. package based R 4.2, following helper functions install required dependencies:
code: devtools::install_github("Omics-Data-Harmonization-EBP/PRECISION.seq.augmented") devtools::install_github("cran/PoissonSeq") ## from CRAN CRAN.packages <- function(pkg){     new.pkg <- pkg[!(pkg %in% installed.packages()[, "Package"])]     if (length(new.pkg))          install.packages(new.pkg, dependencies = TRUE) } CRAN.packages(c("BiocManager", "caret", "e1071", "glmnet", "pamr", "mclust", "cluster", "factoextra", "som", "digest"))  ## from Bioconductor Bioconductor.packages <- function(pkg){     new.pkg <- pkg[!(pkg %in% installed.packages()[, "Package"])]     if (length(new.pkg))          BiocManager::install(new.pkg, dependencies = TRUE) } Bioconductor.packages(c("Biobase", "BiocGenerics", "edgeR", "EDASeq", "RUVSeq", "DESeq2", "preprocessCore", "sva"))  ## from GitHub devtools::install_github("cran/PoissonSeq")

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: full package documentation detailed function parameters examples can found package documentation website.

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: load.augmented.data() - Load pre-generated augmented miRNA-seq datasets. Data downloaded GitHub loaded storage previously downloaded cleanup.augmented.data() - Remove cached augmented data

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: create.precision.cluster() - Creates main analysis object clustering evaluation handling data results create.precision.classification() - Creates main analysis object classification evaluation handling data results biological.effects() - Apply biological effects amplification factors handling.effects() - Modulate handling artifacts test datasets

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: package implements multiple data harmonization techniques applicable clustering classification: harmon.() - Apply following harmonization methods sequentially harmon.TC() - Total Count normalization (scaling library size) harmon.UQ() - Upper Quartile normalization (scaling 75th percentile) harmon.med() - Median normalization (scaling median count) harmon.TMM() - Trimmed Mean M-values normalization (edgeR) harmon.DESeq() - DESeq2 normalization (geometric mean approach) harmon.PoissonSeq() - PoissonSeq normalization (robust -dispersed Poisson model) harmon.QN() - Quantile normalization harmon.SVA() - Surrogate Variable Analysis batch correction harmon.RUVr() - Remove Unwanted Variation (residuals) harmon.RUVs() - Remove Unwanted Variation (control samples) harmon.RUVg() - Remove Unwanted Variation (control genes) harmon.ComBat.Seq() - ComBat-seq batch effect adjustment

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: package implements multiple clustering approaches various distance metrics: cluster.() - Apply following clustering methods sequentially cluster.hc() - Hierarchical clustering multiple distance metrics (Euclidean distance, Pearson correlation, Spearman correlation) cluster.kmeans() - K-means clustering configurable starting points iteration parameters cluster.pam() - Partitioning Around Medoids distance metric options hierarchical clustering (Euclidean, Pearson, Spearman). cluster.som() - Self-Organizing Maps non-linear dimensionality reduction clustering, particularly suited high-dimensional data cluster.mnm() - Gaussian Mixture Model clustering automated model selection using BIC.

title: A Framework for Evaluating Depth Normalization Methods in miRNA Sequencing Data
text: package implements multiple learning methods sample classification evaluate normalization affects predictive performance across training validation datasets: classification.() - Apply following clustering methods sequentially classification.knn() - k-Nearest Neighbor classification classification.svm() - Support Vector Machine classification classification.pam() - Prediction Analysis Microarrays using nearest shrunken centroids, built-feature selection classification.lasso() - Logistic Regression LASSO regularization automatic feature selection reduced overfitting classification.ranfor() - Random Forest classification

what: Apply all classification methods to a precision object — classification.all

title: Apply all classification methods to a precision object — classification.all
Apply all classification methods to a precision object — classification.all
text: object precision object containing harmonized training testing data slots harmon.train.data, harmon.test1.data harmon.test2.data, respectively. threshold_method character string specifying thresholding method. Options : - "cv": Use cross-validation optimize threshold. - "none": Use genes without applying threshold.

title: Apply all classification methods to a precision object — classification.all
text: Updated precision object classification results added   classification.result slot.

title: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Classification — classification.knn
text: function applies KNN classification harmonized data input precision object containing. supports two thresholding methods: cross-validation optimize number neighbors (k) fixed k value 1.

title: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Classification — classification.knn
K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Classification — classification.knn
text: object precision object containing harmonized data. Must contain slots harmon.train.data harmonized training data harmon.test1.data harmon.test2.data harmonized test data. threshold_method character string specifying thresholding method. Use "cv" cross-validation determine optimal k, "none" use fixed k = 1. kfold integer specifying number folds cross-validation. parameter used threshold_method set "cv". folds optional list pre-specified folds cross-validation. provided, folds used instead generating new ones.

title: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) Classification — classification.knn
text: input object updated KNN classification results added  classification.result slot, including predicted classes  associated metrics.

title: Classification with LASSO Logistic Regression — classification.lasso
Classification with LASSO Logistic Regression — classification.lasso
text: object precision object containing harmonized data. Must contain slots harmon.train.data harmonized training data harmon.test1.data harmon.test2.data harmonized test data. threshold_method character string specifying thresholding method. Use "cv" cross-validation determine optimal k, "none" use genes without thresholding. "none" used, small lambda value applied effectively include genes model, may useful datasets genes relevant. kfold integer specifying number folds cross-validation. parameter used threshold_method set "cv".

title: MiRNA Sequencing Benchmark Data — data.benchmark
text: Myxofibrosarcoma (MXF) pleomorphic malignant fibrous histiocytoma (PMFH) two common aggressive subtypes genetically complex soft tissue sarcoma. dataset includes three libraries used sequencing 54 individual tumor samples. Library preparation read capture processed single experienced technician one run.

text: object precision object containing raw data. Harmonization applied slots raw.train.data, raw.test1.data, raw.test2.data (applicable), containing list data label elements. add.raw Logical. TRUE, add raw data harmonized data

title: Apply all harmonization methods to a precision object — harmon.all
text: precision object harmonization results added   slots harmon.train.data, harmon.test1.data, harmon.test2.data   (applicable).

title: Apply all harmonization methods to a precision object — harmon.all
text: following harmonization methods applied data: Harmonization (add.raw = TRUE) Total Count (TC) (harmon.TC) Upper Quartile (UQ) (harmon.UQ) Median (median) (harmon.med) Trimmed Median Means (TMM) (harmon.TMM) DESeq (harmon.DESeq) PoissonSeq (harmon.PoissonSeq) Quantile Normalization (QN) (harmon.QN) Remove Unwanted Variation (RUVg, RUVr, RUVs)       (harmon.RUVg), (harmon.RUVr),    (harmon.RUVs)

what: Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
title: Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
text: function loads augmented dataset. dataset previously downloaded, download package GitHub release. checks integrity downloaded file using SHA256 hash ensure file corrupted tampered . supports persistent storage user's R data directory temporary (R-session) storage. temporary storage useful testing purposes want keep data R session ends. using temporary storage (temp=TRUE), file automatically removed R session ends (using quit()). delete cached data, use cleanup.augmented.data function. function also allows re-downloading file even exists, based `force.redownload` parameter. load.augmented.data() returns loaded R object, list containing augmented benchmark test datasets.

title: Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
text: temp Logical. TRUE, store file temporary directory remove R session ends. Default FALSE (persistent storage). force.redownload Logical. TRUE, force re-download even file exists passes integrity check.

title: Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
text: loaded R object, list containing augmented benchmark test datasets.

title: Load augmented data from GitHub (with integrity check) — load.augmented.data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # First-time load: downloads & caches persistently augmented.data <- load.augmented.data()  # Uses cached file if valid augmented.data <- load.augmented.data()  # Force re-download augmented.data <- load.augmented.data(force.redownload = TRUE)  # Store in tempdir() instead of persistent (will be cleaned up when session ends) augmented.data <- load.augmented.data(temp = TRUE)  # Access benchmark and test datasets benchmark <- augmented.data$benchmark test <- augmented.data$test  # Manually cleanup cached data cleanup.augmented.data() } # }

title: Precision Class — precision-class
text: class handles data results PRECISION.seq.augmented package. includes raw training test data, harmonized data various normalization methods, classification results, clustering results. Use create.precision.classification create instance classification tasks, create.precision.cluster create instance clustering tasks.

title: Precision Class — precision-class
text: raw.train.data list containing training data (raw.train.data$data) labels (raw.train.data$label) raw.test1.data list containing first test dataset (raw.test1.data$data) labels (raw.test1.data$label) raw.test2.data list containing second test dataset (raw.test2.data$data) labels (raw.test2.data$label) harmon.train.data list harmonized training data raw.train.data various methods harmon.test1.data list harmonized first test data raw.test1.data various methods harmon.test2.data list harmonized second test data raw.test2.data various methods classification.result list containing results classification tasks cluster.result list containing results clustering tasks
